title: French PM and far right chief clash in raucous election debate
summary: French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal and the chief of the Rassemblement National Jordan Bardella exchanged accusations on Tuesday in a sometimes bruising live TV encounter where discussion of issues was often drowned by a cacophony of voices.

title: WikiLeaks’ Assange pleads guilty in deal with US that secures his freedom
summary: The plea was entered Wednesday morning in federal court in Saipan, the capital of the Northern Mariana Islands, a US commonwealth in the Pacific. The Australian whistleblower, who admitted guilt for publishing US military secrets, will fly to Canberra within hours.

title: Euro 2024: France fail to overcome Poland in their final group match
summary: Les Bleus qualified from Group D in second place after a 1-1 draw against Poland in Dortmund on Tuesday. Kylian Mbappé marked his return to the pitch with a penalty, but Poland followed suit to draw level.

title: France's first small nuclear reactor project
summary: Start-up company Jimmy Energy is exploring a small model designed to supply heat to a factory belonging to the Cristal Union sugar group in the department of Marne to the east of Paris.

title: Former Russian defense minister and chief of staff prosecuted by the International Criminal Court
summary: After Vladimir Putin, the ICC has issued two arrest warrants for Sergei Shoigu and Valery Gerasimov for war crimes and crimes against humanity. Both are charged with attacks on Ukrainian power plants.

title: 80 years on, civilians recall the Battle of Normandy
summary: On the occasion of the commemorations of the D-Day landings and the violent battles that followed to liberate France, 65 witnesses, now aged from 86 to 104, have shared recollections of this period. Some had never spoken before. Talking about these traumas revived buried memories.

title: Kenyan anti-tax protesters storm parliament
summary: Hundreds of protesters broke through barriers erected by the police outside parliament in the capital Nairobi on Tuesday, with police firing live rounds and the parliament complex going on fire, according to Amnesty International Kenya. Medical workers reported five people killed.

title: Brazil’s Supreme Court votes to decriminalize possession of marijuana for personal use
summary: With final votes cast on Tuesday, at least seven justices voted in favor of decriminalization since deliberations began in 2015, a majority on the 11-person court.

title: 21 Nigerien soldiers killed in ambush by 'terrorist group,' ruling junta says
summary: The statement Tuesday evening did not specify which group was behind the attack which happened near the country's border with Burkina Faso. Niger is struggling with a deadly security crisis involving several armed groups.

title: Sociologists Maxime Cornet and Clément Le Ludec: 'Humans are essential for training AI'
summary: Behind artificial intelligence, there's a whole process of collecting, verifying, and annotating data carried out by humans. French sociologists Maxime Cornet and Clément Le Ludec explain that this is largely outsourced, notably to Madagascar.

title: Investigation: how Israel deliberately targeted cameras filming Gaza live
summary: On November 2, 2023, the cameras of news agencies were the target of several explosions in Gaza. Le Monde's investigation revealed that they had been targeted by Israeli army tanks.

title: Le Monde's pick of the top summer festivals 2024
summary: Feel the rhythm of electronic music with your toes in the water, listen to the conversation between a violin and a bird: Across France this summer, culture can be best experienced outdoors.

title: EU launches formal accession negotiations with Ukraine and Moldova
summary: The membership negotiations began on Tuesday, a landmark move aimed in particular at signaling a vote of confidence in Ukraine's future.

title: US surgeon general declares gun violence a 'public health crisis'
summary: Appointed by the President, this senior federal official is responsible for prevention on public health issues, although his practical powers are very limited. In 2022, there were 48,204 gun-related deaths in the country, including suicides.

title: Israel's top court rules army must draft young ultra-Orthodox Jewish men
summary: Israel's High Court of Justice ruled that 'the state must act to enforce the law' on conscription, ending long-standing exemptions for ultra-Orthodox Jewish men studying in religious seminaries, an issue which could topple the country's coalition government.

title: UNRWA reports 10 children lose legs every day in Gaza
summary: The aid agency for Palestinian refugees also said on Tuesday that its funding would run out at the end of August.

title: The complicated restructuring of Ukraine's debt
summary: Major asset managers are demanding that Ukraine, in the midst of war with Russia, repay its debts, even though the country desperately needs financing to ensure its defense and survival.

title: Sociologist Dominique Schnapper: 'Today, the president provokes rejection in a way that weakens our institutions'
summary: Sociologist Dominique Schnapper analyzes how the principles of freedom and equality that underpin democracy can be turned against it, which can lead to a climate of hatred and transform adversaries into enemies.

title: 'People hate you': The French are increasingly rejecting Macron
summary: The French president is omnipresent, despite having pledged to let Gabriel Attal lead the campaign for the upcoming elections. Yet he has never provoked so much hostility, even within his own camp.

title: Caught between a need for manpower and nationalism lies Japan's taboo immigration policy
summary: Facing severe labor shortage, Japan is increasing recruitment procedures for foreign workers, but not officially welcoming the unskilled. In the country, the subject of immigration, in general, remains sensitive.

title: Singapore announces seizing over $4 billion in dirty money since 2019
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said he was determined to 'safeguard Singapore's reputation as a trusted financial center,' after a dirty money scandal marred the Southeast Asian country's reputation last year.

title: 2024 French election: First TV debate misses the stakes of a major election
summary: Prime Minister Gabriel Attal clashed with the president of far-right Rassemblement National, Jordan Bardella, and a representative of the left-wing alliance, Manuel Bompard, in a debate that alternated between financial quibbles and a catalog of promises.

title: 'What would the national football team represent in a France governed by the far right?'
summary: Les Bleus, currently competing in Euro 2024, will be more than ever a political issue during the campaign of the June 30 and July 7 parliamentary elections, writes football columnist Jérôme Latta.

title: NATO appoints Dutch PM Rutte as new secretary general
summary: The outgoing Dutch prime minister will take over the helm from Norway's Jens Stoltenberg, in a world of political uncertainty and a Europe at war.

title: Najat Vallaud-Belkacem: 'At the ballot box, let's beat those who are putting a target on our backs'
summary: The former Socialist education minister addresses all French people of foreign origin, or perceived as such, and invites them to be proud and to go out to vote in the legislative elections.

title: Protests in Kenya turn into riots
summary: At least five people were killed and parliament was briefly seized on Tuesday during protests against President William Ruto's finance reform.

title: Journalist Abdallah Al-Hajj's first-hand account of the Israeli assault on Al-Shifa hospital
summary: As part of the Gaza Project investigation with Forbidden Stories, Le Monde met with the Palestinian videojournalist in Doha, where he recounted the violence of the hospital's occupation in February.

title: American CEOs rally behind Donald Trump
summary: Despite their mixed feelings about him, America's top business leaders have increasingly rallied behind the Republican candidate because of what they see as Joe Biden's overly left-wing policies.

title: Biden announces pardons for US military staff convicted under homosexuality ban
summary: The US president announced pardons for thousands of military personnel who had been convicted under a law banning homosexuality in the US armed forces, as well as allowing their military documents to be amended.

title: Ukraine officially begins EU accession negotiations
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected in Brussels on Thursday, at the European summit, to sign a security pledge with Europe.

title: US reporter Evan Gershkovich's trial begins in Russia
summary: The 'Wall Street Journal' reporter was originally arrested for spying in Russia in March 2023, he could face up to 20 years in a penal colony.

title: 'Emmanuel Macron and Jean-Luc Mélenchon are scarecrows in their respective camps'
summary: Despite the backlash they each provoke on the ground, the president and the leader of La France Inoumise continue to intervene in the electoral debate. Their supporters are dreaming of a campaign without either of them, observes Le Monde columnist Solenn de Royer.

title: French elections: High turnout expected in snap vote
summary: Voters are motivated by the possibility of a change of government, as well as by the prospect of the extreme right coming to power. According to various polls, they are likely to turn out in large numbers.

title: Paris court upholds validity of arrest warrant for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad
summary: An international arrest warrant issued against Bashar al-Assad for alleged complicity in war crimes during Syria's civil war remains valid, a Paris court has ruled.

title: Kenya's president withdraws finance bill after anti-tax protest deaths
summary: Hundreds of protesters broke through barriers erected by the police outside parliament in the capital Nairobi on Tuesday, with police firing live rounds and more than 20 protestors killed.

title: French elections, seen from Germany: Outcome could cause an 'extremely serious crisis'
summary: Emmanuel Macron's dissolution of the Assemblée Nationale stunned German political leaders of all stripes, who fear that the far-right Rassemblement National party, perceived as being 'deeply Germanophobic,' could win.

title: 'Ukrainians have reached the stage where, exhausted by a sprint, they realize they actually have to run a marathon'
summary: The methodical destruction by Russian forces of the country's energy infrastructure, and the chronic power cuts it is causing outside the combat zones show the extent to which war has taken hold in Ukraine, observes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: A left-wing maverick's campaign against the far right: 'We're facing headwinds'
summary: François Ruffin, a dissenter from the La France Insoumise party, is taking on the far-right Rassemblement National, which scored 44% in his northern constituency in the EU elections. He must also contend with voters' rejection of La France Insoumise founder, Jean-Luc Mélenchon.

title: The Stade de France: From 1998 World Cup to 2024 Olympics, a beacon of hope for Paris suburbs
summary: The Stade de France will host athletics and the closing ceremony at the Paris Games, which kick off on July 26. Since its inauguration in 1998, the stadium has not effectively become anchored in the community of the suburb of Saint-Denis, where it is located. But it has hosted significant events in the nation's history and stands as a proud landmark.

title: Euro 2024: Belgium to face France, Ukraine bows out
summary: Ukraine's brave run came to an agonizing end as they became the first team since the tournament increased to 24 teams not to progress with four points.

title: Paris 2024: Alex Morgan omitted from USA women's Olympics football squad
summary: Morgan, who was part of the USA team which won gold at the 2012 London Games, said she was 'disappointed' not to represent the USA at the Paris Games this year.

title: In the shadow of the war in Gaza, Israel continues its annexation of the West Bank
summary: At the request of ultranationalist Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich, part of the administrative functions of the Palestinian territory, which has been under military authority since 1967, were transferred to civilian control.

title: Bolivian president warns 'irregular' military deployment underway in capital, raising coup fears
summary: Bolivian President Luis Arce on Wednesday called for democracy to be respected after soldiers and tanks deployed outside government buildings and tried to knock down a door of the presidential palace.
